subs.text: March 9

@StanphylCap @Salty_WingLove Agree on the torque factor for EVs. Disagree that 0-10 has to happen that quickly every single time. I could do a video to prove my case (just let OFF the throttle), but it's not worth the time and effort. You clearly aren't going to change your mind even with evidence. Cheers!
subs.rawText: @StanphylCap @Salty_WingLove Agree on the torque factor for EVs. Disagree that 0-10 has to happen that quickly every single time. I could do a video to prove my case (just let OFF the throttle), but it's not worth the time and effort. You clearly aren't going to change your mind even with evidence. Cheers!

subs.text: @StanphylCap @Salty_WingLove I drive an EV now (Nissan Leaf) and while it can accelerate quicker than most ICE cars, I have complete control over that acceleration. I also had it during my Tesla test drive.
subs.rawText: @StanphylCap @Salty_WingLove I drive an EV now (Nissan Leaf) and while it can accelerate quicker than most ICE cars, I have complete control over that acceleration. I also had it during my Tesla test drive.

subs.text: @StanphylCap @Salty_WingLove I'll grant the general statement you made can be true. But, wouldn't the weight difference depend on the vehicle by comparison? Tesla's don't universally weigh more than all other car makes and models. Quicker acceleration off the line is totally dependent on the driver as well.
subs.rawText: @StanphylCap @Salty_WingLove I'll grant the general statement you made can be true. But, wouldn't the weight difference depend on the vehicle by comparison? Tesla's don't universally weigh more than all other car makes and models. Quicker acceleration off the line is totally dependent on the driver as well.

subs.text: @StanphylCap @Salty_WingLove @jeffkibuule, you mentioned you have 60k miles on your Tesla. As a single data point only, I'm curious what you think about this based on your experience.
subs.rawText: @StanphylCap @Salty_WingLove @jeffkibuule, you mentioned you have 60k miles on your Tesla. As a single data point only, I'm curious what you think about this based on your experience.

subs.text: @Gartenberg You can change to Chrome OS 100 Beta Channel and that will keep everything. Going forward a version keeps data. Reverting to a lesser version wipes data.
subs.rawText: @Gartenberg You can change to Chrome OS 100 Beta Channel and that will keep everything. Going forward a version keeps data. Reverting to a lesser version wipes data.

subs.text: @janole @koehntopp Not currently. You have to download a prior version to removable media and run through the restore process. Most people don’t know where to find prior versions. And auto-update will happen again anyway. 🤷🏼‍♂️
subs.rawText: @janole @koehntopp Not currently. You have to download a prior version to removable media and run through the restore process. Most people don’t know where to find prior versions. And auto-update will happen again anyway. 🤷🏼‍♂️

subs.text: @koehntopp @janole Maybe. Even in Windows you can pause updates though. Depends on how this gets implemented, maybe with regular reminders of update availability.
subs.rawText: @koehntopp @janole Maybe. Even in Windows you can pause updates though. Depends on how this gets implemented, maybe with regular reminders of update availability.
